stem: A client has been receiving long-term TPN with 20% lipid emulsion daily. Review the provided documentation. Which condition is the client MOST likely developing?

rationale.correct: The client is most likely developing Lipid Overload Syndrome (a1). This syndrome occurs when IV lipids are administered too rapidly or over a prolonged period, leading to a significant increase in triglycerides (>1,000 mg/dL) and overwhelming the reticuloendothelial system. The classic triad of Lipid Overload Syndrome includes fever, splenomegaly/hepatomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. The provided exhibits show elevated triglycerides (1,150 mg/dL), low platelets (54,000), fever (102.2°F), and enlarged spleen and liver.
clinicalPearls: Triglycerides > 400 mg/dL increase the risk of pancreatitis. Triglycerides > 1,000 mg/dL increase the risk of Lipid Overload Syndrome.
Excess lipids can accumulate in the spleen and liver, impairing their ability to filter blood effectively.

Management of Lipid Overload Syndrome includes stopping the lipid infusion, monitoring for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and restarting the infusion at a slower rate once the condition resolves.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'Simple Hypertriglyceridemia' (a2) due to the elevated triglyceride level.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Differentiate between a high lab value and a systemic syndrome. The presence of fever and organ enlargement (splenomegaly/hepatomegaly) indicates a systemic issue beyond just an isolated lab abnormality. Focus on identifying systemic cues.

mnemonic.title: Fat-Fever-Fail
mnemonic.expansion: F-Fatty blood (>1000 mg/dL). F-Fever. F-Filter Failure (Spleen/Liver).
